title-part.text: INDEXING SCHEME RELATING TO ASPECTS CROSS-CUTTING VEHICLE TECHNOLOGY
City movers, small sized city motor vehicles
Racing vehicles, e.g. Formula one, Karts
Trailers, e.g. full trailers or caravans
Vehicles with lowerable bed or chassis, e.g. to facilitate loading
Boom carrying vehicles, e.g. for irrigation
Walk behind vehicles, e.g. motorized wheel barrows
having track following mechanism for lateral stability
Multi-axle long vehicles, with independently drivable or steerable wheels
Vehicles having steerable wheels mounted on a vertically moving column
Climbing vehicles, e.g. facade climbing devices
Movable platforms, Load ramps, e.g. working platforms
Industrial applications, e.g. pipe inspection vehicles
Other vehicles not covered by groups B60Y2200/10 to B60Y2200/60
Electric vehicles with power supply external to vehicle, e.g. trolley buses or trams
Purposes or special features of road vehicle drive control systems

reference.text: for systems using conjoint control of multiple vehicle sub-units B60W30/00

title-part.text: Stability in turns or during cornering
Improving turning performance, e.g. agility of a vehicle in a curve
Predicting or avoiding probable or impending collision
Taking automatic action to adjust vehicle attitude or components thereof in preparation for collision, e.g. adjusting bumpers or wheels or braking for nose dropping
Taking automatic action to avoid collision, e.g. braking or steering
Predicting travel path or likelihood of collision
the prediction being responsive to vehicle dynamic parameters
the prediction being responsive to traffic or environmental parameters
Control of distance between vehicles, e.g. keeping a distance to preceding vehicle
Automatically following the path of a preceding lead vehicle, e.g. "electronic tow-bar"
with provision for special action when the preceding vehicle comes to a halt, e.g. stop-and-go
Start-stop drive, e.g. in a traffic jam
Rocking, i.e. fast change between forward and reverse
at stand still, e.g. engine in idling state
with torque flow from driveshaft to engine, i.e. engine being driven by vehicle
without torque flow between driveshaft and engine, e.g. with clutch disengaged or transmission in neutral
Preventing, or responsive to skidding of wheels
Propulsion control with common controlling member for different functions
Propulsion control with control means using analogue circuits, relays or mechanical links
Selecting between different operative modes, e.g. comfort and performance modes
Preventing damage resulting from overload or excessive wear of the driveline
Preventing of breakage of drive line components, e.g. parts of the gearing
Excessive wear or burn out of friction elements, e.g. clutches
Controlling power parameters of the driveline, e.g. determining the required power
characterised by the working point of the engine, e.g. by using engine output chart
Avoiding stall or over-speed of the engine
Controlling power supply to auxiliary devices
Improvement of gear change, e.g. synchronisation or smoothing gear shift
Power-up or power-down of the driveline, e.g. start up of a cold engine
related to low temperature conditions, e.g. high viscosity of hydraulic fluid
related or induced by the clutch
related or induced by the engine
related to drive shaft torsion, e.g. driveline oscillations
Reducing road induced vibrations, suppressing road noise
Adaptation to external conditions, e.g. road surface conditions
related to towing or towed situations
related to stationary vehicle situations, e.g. parked vehicles
Kneeling, e.g. for letting passengers on or off
Lowering or adjusting the floor for loading or unloading
Adjusting floor height to loading ramp level
Jacking-up for changing tyre or for vehicle inspection
Control of lock-up type clutches, e.g. in a torque converter
Control of clutches to regulate engine speed or torque
Reducing engagement shocks in main clutch
Control of clutch touch point, e.g. kiss point
Control of secondary clutches in drivelines
Control of engine inlet air duct by secondary means
Control of engine at idle speed
Engine direct start by injecting fuel and fire
Engine push start or restart by use of vehicle kinetic energy
Engine start by use of flywheel kinetic energy
Driving or powering of engine accessories
by reducing drag torque, e.g. by closing valves to reduce pumping
Engine overload, high loads on engine
Engine torque vibration dampers, e.g. flywheels, dual-mass-springs
Control of electric machines, e.g. problems related to electric motors or generators
Mechanical lock-up, e.g. using brake to immobilise the rotor
Drag run or drag torque compensation, e.g. motor to drive engine with drag torque or engine speed is brought to start speed before injection and firing
Reduce shocks on mode change, e.g. during engine shutdown
High load on electric machines, e.g. overheating
Motor boost, e.g. short time overpower
Facilitate disengaging of gears, e.g. by inducing a torque reversal
Dither torque , e.g. to remove tooth butting
Torque reversal, e.g. avoid clunks when changing between driving and coasting
Repartition of braking force, e.g. friction braking versus regenerative braking
Battery protection from overload or overcharge
Responses or measures related to driver conditions

reference.text: for propulsion units B60K28/02, related to driving style L60W40/08B

title-part.text: Actuating a signal or alarm device
Leading to automatic stopping of the vehicle
Disabling particular vehicle functions, e.g. to affect the driving style
Minimizing space with more compact designs or arrangements
Reducing production costs, e.g. by redesign
by interchangeable parts, e.g. new part adapting to old design
Reducing damages in case of crash, e.g. by improving battery protection
Noise generation, e.g. drive noise to warn pedestrians that an electric vehicle is approaching
Hydraulic energy storages, e.g. hydraulic accumulators
Pneumatic energy storages, e.g. pressure air tanks
Generator sets, engine and generator as one unit
Peltier or Thomson elements for cooling or heating
by power from overhead cables using trolleys
by power from domestic supply, e.g. plug in supplies
Actuators for moving a controlled member
Manual actuators, i.e. input levers or linkages therefor
providing feel, e.g. with feedback force
Electro-magnetic actuators, e.g. with an electromagnet not rotating for moving a clutching member
Mechanical assistance, i.e. using springs or accumulators without feedback control
Servo-motors, e.g. electric or fluidic with feedback control
Electromagnetic clutches, e.g. powder type clutches
of wet type, e.g. using multiple lamellae
Gas Engines, e.g. using LPG, natural gas or gasifiers
Exhaust gas reformers, e.g. treated by fuel cells
Engine start hydraulic or electric motors
Vibration dampers, e.g. dual mass flywheels
Electric Machines, e.g. motors or generators
Clutch motors, i.e. having rotating stators
Arrangements of controllers for electric machines, e.g. inverters
Manual or semi-automatic, e.g. automated manual transmissions
with intermeshing planetary gears, e.g. Ravigneaux
Shaft brakes, e.g. input shaft brakes
Power shifting, e.g. without interruption of drive torque
Gearshift position determination, e.g. check of neutral position
Drive shafts, output shafts or propeller shafts
Skid-steer systems, e.g. for tracked vehicles
Aggregate identification or specification, e.g. using RFID
Mount clips, snap-fit, e.g. quick fit with elastic members
Production or manufacturing of vehicle parts
Materials or fluids with special properties
